result.execSummary:
The defendant Anthony J Langlois was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Theft-False Representation <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).
  • Theft-False Representation <=$2500, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.20(1)(d).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
With Huber. Release for standard conditions if imposed.
Consecutive to: Any other sentence.

miscConds.notes: Restitution for the Alzheimer's Assocation to be paid as a condition of probation before costs or fees.
Costs to be paid as a condition of probation.

Submit to an AODA assessment, follow through with any treatment, counseling.  No use or possession of alcohol or illegal drugs/drug paraphernalia. Comply with random urine screens.  Maintain absolute sobriety. No use or possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription. Valid prescriptions only with prior agent approval and to be taken only in the manner they are ordered.
Inform agent of all prescriptions.

No Contact with any victim or with the Alzheimer's Association. Maintain employment and/or school combination. Defendant to write a letter of apology to the Alzheimer's Assocation. (Already provided to DA). 
  If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged/terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collection may include income assignment.

Letter dated 4/15/17 filed by defendant requesting the Judgment of Conviction be amended as to the term of probation.

4/20/17 - Judge Maxwell reviewed and ordered the following: The JOC should either say 1 yr prob on each count consecutive to each other - or probably more accurately - 2 years probation on each count concurrent to each other.....either way - I don't believe the DOC is giving him four years probation, but this guy likes to write letters.
